fields.summary: User Console: About your cloud shows version 3.2.0

comments.body: Where is the console pulling the version info from?  [~dkavanagh], can you provide this info?
This is hard coded in eucaconsole/__init__.py. I'll change it to 3.3
perhaps I should change it to 3.2.1 in the maint/3.2/testing branch? (I'll wait for confirmation)
For 3.3+ can we read it from somewhere instead of hard coding it?

I assume it would be better for the version to be "applied" during packaging? I also don't think the config file is necessarily the right place for it. How does eucalyptus proper do it? I could read this from a separate version file.

David, yes please change this to 3.2.1 for /maint/3.2/testing.  That's the crux of this bug which was found in 3.2.1 testing. 

Agree with Tim on this, it would be better if we did not hard code this.  Perhaps [~gholms] or [~mspaulding] could offer a suggestion?
The eucalyptus repository has a VERSION file that contains the correct version information. We could probably use that.
And then we just don't worry about build from source and the version shown there?

Yep, we should use the canonical version info from the VERSION file AND
append the extra version that is passed in during build.

This lets us differentiate packaged builds from source.

On Tue, Jan 22, 2013 at 8:43 PM, Matt Spaulding (JIRA) <




-- 

*Neil Soman - *Co-founder and Director of Engineering

*Eucalyptus Systems*

www.eucalyptus.com

Depends on how you choose to do it. The fix I'm thinking of would generate a version.py file at build time that gets included with the rest of the console code. It would not be something that we set in a configuration file and would work for both source builds and package builds.
That would work too. We just need the extra version info somehow.
I'm linking this to euca-4812, which also relates to versioning.  We need a short term fix for 3.2.1 and a long term plan to address how we handle our versioning across the product components.
Be careful not to expose extra version info to regular users.  Disclosing patchlevel information to them is a security risk.

What is the "extra" information? I'm in favor of the packaging script using the common VERSION file to write a version.py file. I would suggest we put a default version.py file in eucaconsole which has version set to "development" so we don't mistake a proper build from a source installation.

The admin tools' {{setup.py}} file has an example of how one might use the top-level VERSION file to feed version info to the python code.

"Extra version" refers to supplemental version info that is supplied with a {{configure}} option at build time.  Packages supply their release numbers here, for instance.  It is meant to appear in log files and a few other places to assist with debugging, and should _not_ be exposed to regular users because it can expose information about patch levels.

Verified in security branch:
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 3.2.1
Release     : 0.0.497.20130123git4064231c.el6
